title: 107_s1501
content: The "Safe Food Act of 2001" establishes an independent Food Safety Administration and consolidates various food safety and inspection services and agencies. It also includes additional authorities for the Administration and sets limitations on authorization of appropriations. Congress finds that the safety and security of the US food supply requires efficient management of food safety regulations. Pressures include emerging pathogens, an aging population at high risk for foodborne illnesses, increased imports without adequate monitoring, and the need for adequate inspection of the domestic food industry. Federal food safety efforts should be scientifically supported. The Food Safety Administration Act aims to establish a single agency responsible for regulating food safety and labeling, conducting inspections to prevent food-borne illnesses, and consolidating functions currently performed by multiple Federal agencies to improve efficiency. The Food Safety Administration Act aims to establish a single agency responsible for regulating food safety and labeling, conducting inspections to prevent food-borne illnesses, and consolidating functions currently performed by multiple Federal agencies to improve efficiency for the protection and improvement of public health. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The Food Safety Administration Act defines key terms such as "Administration" as the agency established under section 4, "Administrator" as the appointed head of the agency, and "food safety law" as including various acts related to food safety, labeling, and inspection. The Food Safety Administration Act defines key terms related to food safety, labeling, and inspection, as designated by the President through Executive order. Establishment of Independent Food Safety Administration. The "Food Safety Administration" is established as an independent agency in the Executive branch, headed by the Administrator of Food Safety appointed by the President. The Administrator is responsible for enforcing food safety laws and overseeing federal food safety inspection, enforcement, and research efforts to protect public health. The Food Safety Administration focuses on scientifically assessing risks to public health, setting standards for safe food, coordinating research and education programs, responding to foodborne illness outbreaks, and integrating food safety activities with State and local agencies. SEC. 5. CONSOLIDATION OF SEPARATE FOOD SAFETY AND INSPECTION SERVICES AND AGENCIES. The Administration will take over functions related to food safety laws from specified Federal agencies including the Food Safety and Inspection Service, the Center for Food Safety and Applied Nutrition, and the Center for Veterinary Medicine of the Food and Drug Administration. The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration under the Department of Commerce administers the Seafood Inspection Program. The President can designate other offices or agencies to carry out this Act. Assets, funds, personnel, and unexpended funds related to transferred functions from Federal agencies will be transferred to the Administration for specific purposes. After the transfer of functions from a Federal agency, references to that agency in connection with food safety laws will now refer to the Administration. The transfer will not affect any existing administrative actions or agreements in effect before the transfer date. The transfer of functions from a Federal agency to the Administration will not affect any ongoing civil actions, proceedings, or applications pending before the agency before the transfer date. SEC. 6. ADDITIONAL AUTHORITIES OF THE ADMINISTRATION. The Administrator of the Administration may appoint officers, employees, experts, and consultants in accordance with relevant provisions of the United States Code. They can also establish bureaus, offices, and divisions within the Administration. The Administrator of the Administration can appoint officers, employees, experts, and consultants as needed. They may also establish bureaus, offices, and divisions within the Administration and prescribe rules to perform their duties. SEC. 7. LIMITATION ON AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. The amount authorized to be appropriated for this Act for the fiscal year shall not exceed the previous year's appropriation for the same purpose if the current year's appropriations have not been made yet. SEC. 8. EFFECTIVE DATE. This Act will take effect 180 days after enactment or as directed by the President within that period.
